22. 2. recentem terrorem, etc.: the war-chariots at first caused some confusion among the assaulting party (the Romans), but soon became useless on the hilly ground, and mixed in with the thick ranks of their own countrymen3 hostium must, from Tacitus' point of view, be the CaledonianS.

4. minime equestris: the ground not being suited to horseSâ€š this battle of the war-chariotS, which would properly be ranked with cavalry engagementS, became minime equestris. The same ex- pression, minime equestria more pugnae, is used by Livy (xxii. 47) with reference to the battle of Cannae, where, as here, the horse became useless from the closeness of the action and the nature of the ground.

5. aegre clivo astantes: the manuscripts read egra diu aut stante3 manifestly corrupt. Kritz reads olivo instantem Halm and Draeger, adstantes. It will be noted that in the round hand of the manuscripts oliv could be easily mistaken for diu. This ap- pears to refer to the CaledoniansÍ¾ while the following indicative clause, ac saepe ...incursabant, describes both parties. In this difficult passage, Kritz (following Wex) reads aequa nostrie for equestres of the manuscriptSâ€š and instantes for aut stante, making the confusion refer to the Romans. It is evidentâ€š however, from the following chapter, circumire terga vincentium, that the Romans were successful so far, and were making their way trium- phantly up the hill. The events of the battle had been as follows: first, the skirmishing ominum next, the assault made by the Bata- vians and Tungrians3 third, the joining of the war-chariots in the battle, after the cavalry had been routed (Interim . . . haerebant).
